description: The verb is from Middle English empanellen, from Anglo-Norman and Old French empaneller.

entries.meaning: (law) A list of jurors; a panel.
examples: The Maior [â€¦] began to call the empanels.

verbs.description: empanel (third-person singular simple present empanels, present participle (UK) empanelling or (US) empaneling, simple past and past participle (UK) empanelled or (US) empaneled)

examples: President Biden lent validity to the debate, if not to the idea [of expanding the Supreme Court] itself, by empaneling a commission to examine court expansion and other possible reforms such as term limits for justices.
